title: Provides for the licensure of agents of authorized title insurance companies
summary: Provides for the licensure of authorized title insurance company agents and empowers the insurance department to administer all requirements relating thereto; requires the superintendent of insurance to develop an examination to test qualifications of an individual title insurance agent; exempts certain attorneys and title insurance agents; requires an initial and renewal fee of two hundred dollars for a two year license; relates to commissions of agent of title insurance companies; mandates all funds collected to be fiduciary funds.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2668

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the insurance law, in relation to the licensing of agents of
authorized title insurance companies

PURPOSE/SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
This bill amends
Section 2101 of the
Insurance Law in defining insurance agent and title insurance agent.
This bill amends Section 2103 of the Insurance Law in the following
three ways: 1) By requiring the Superintendent of Insurance to
develop an examination adapted to test the qualifications of an
individual title insurance agent in accordance with subparagraph (b)
of paragraph (2) of subsection (f) of Section 2103 of the Insurance
Law. 2) By providing exemptions from the examination to New York
State licensed attorneys and title insurance agents who on or before
June I, 1994 had acted as an agent of an authorized title insurance
company for a period of 30 months. 3) By requiring an initial and
renewal fee of two hundred dollars for a two year license. This bill
amends Section 2115 of the Insurance Law in relation to the payment
of commissions to agents of title insurance companies. Lastly, this
bill amends section 2120 of the Insurance Law in relation to
treatment of all funds collected as fiduciary funds.

JUSTIFICATION:
New York State is one of only a few
states that does
not require title insurance agents to be licensed. In a hearing held
by the New York State Department of Insurance on February 13, 1991,
all those who testified spoke of the need for licensing of title
insurance agents in this state. Many questions were raised as to the
competence of some title insurance agents. The need to assure
competency of title agents is essential. The bill provides that the
Superintendent of Insurance shall develop an examination to test the
qualification of those wishing to act as a title insurance agent.
Upon successful passage of this examination, the agent would be
issued a two-year license as a title insurance agent. In today's
market, the title insurance agent has the capability of moving from
one title insurance company to another with the business such agent
controls. Title insurers have experienced increases in the number and
severity of agent defalcations in recent years. If the Insurance
Department were given the authority to discipline and remove the
license of any agent who violates the Insurance Law or proves
otherwise untrustworthy, the incidence of fraud would be reduced.
There is a widely felt need in the industry for licensing
of title insurance agents who in many cases do all of the work
involved in effecting a title insurance policy, such as title
searches, clearing titles and filing of documents for the title
companies in the issuance of a title policy. Licensing would elevate

the professionalism and
knowledge of title agents. Inevitably it is the consumer who pays the
price for this fraudulent practice and this legislation will aid in
alleviating that hardship.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
The New York State Insurance
Department shall
administer the licensing procedures and charge a two hundred dollar
fee for a two-year renewable license. There are approximately 600
title agents operating in the state. This would generate about
$120,000 in income for the state, every two years.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect immediately, with provisions.
